senses.de: Equilibrium, or the state of having one's weight evenly distributed, not inclined to any side.
senses.ex: She lost her balance and fell.

Tips.title: Metaphorical Use
Tips.description: Used metaphorically to describe a state of emotional or mental stability.
Tips.example: After a rough week, she found her balance through meditation.

Tips.title: Physical Stability
Tips.description: Relates to physical stability; often used in sports or physical activities.
Tips.example: Gymnasts must have great balance to perform on the beam.

Tips.title: Common Expressions
Tips.description: 'Off balance' means unprepared or surprised, not just physically unsteady.
Tips.example: The sudden question caught her off balance.

senses.de: The difference in value between a country's imports and exports.
senses.ex: The balance of trade figures were released today.

Tips.title: Economics Term
Tips.description: Often connected to economics; understanding the basic economy can help.
Tips.example: Economists analyze the balance of trade to predict financial trends.

Tips.title: Indicator of Health
Tips.description: A positive or negative balance can indicate an economy's health.
Tips.example: A negative trade balance suggests the country imports more than it exports.

senses.de: The amount of money that you have in a bank account.
senses.ex: Please check your balance before withdrawing money.

Tips.title: Financial Planning
Tips.description: Understanding your account balance is crucial for budgeting and planning.
Tips.example: I always check my balance before making a large purchase.

Tips.title: Bank Communications
Tips.description: Banks use 'balance' often in statements and alerts.
Tips.example: My bank sends a monthly balance update via text.

senses.de: To keep or make things equal and right. Like making sure everything in a diet or lifestyle is balanced.
senses.ex: She tries to balance her diet by eating lots of fruits and vegetables.

Tips.title: Life Management
Tips.description: Used to discuss managing different areas of life harmoniously.
Tips.example: Many people find it hard to balance work with their personal lives.

Tips.title: Equality and Fairness
Tips.description: Conveys the idea of fairness, equal attention or resource distribution.
Tips.example: The manager worked hard to balance responsibilities among her team.

senses.de: A device used in physics and chemistry to measure mass precisely.
senses.ex: He used a balance to weigh the chemicals for his experiment.

Tips.title: Precise Instrument
Tips.description: Refers specifically to an instrument for measuring weight in science.
Tips.example: In chemistry class, we used a balance for every experiment.

Equality.wordDefinition:
Equality refers to the state of being equal, in terms of opportunities, rights, and treatment, regardless of differences in gender, ethnicity, religion, or social status.

So, while both balance and equality aim to achieve fairness, they focus on different areas. Balance is applicable more to personal situations, while equality is more applicable to social situations.

Equilibrium.wordDefinition:
Balance and equilibrium both refer to states of stability or harmony, but they are used in slightly different contexts.

Equilibrium refers to a state of balance that is characterized by a lack of change or motion. It often refers to a state in which opposing forces or elements are not just balanced, but also cancel each other out, resulting in a state of rest.

This could be seen in a physics experiment, where two equal and opposite forces cancel each other out to create a state of static equilibrium.

Balance refers to an even distribution or proportion of opposing forces, while equilibrium refers to a state of balance in which no change or motion is occurring.

Evenness.wordDefinition:
Evenness refers to the quality of being consistent or uniform in some respect, like the evenness of a surface or the evenness of someone's character.

Evenness means having a level and consistent state and not showing excessive fluctuations, variations, or irregularities.

Both words are useful depending on the context. Balance is typically used when referring to tasks, activities, or priorities that need to be managed, while evenness is used when describing the nature or appearance of something.

Fair.wordDefinition:
Balance means having equal distribution or proportion of something, whereas the word fair means treating everyone equally and without discrimination.

However, being fair means that each person's preferences and needs are taken into consideration, such as if one person is vegetarian and the other is not, they may get different toppings on their slices to accommodate their individual preferences.

Balance is applicable in situations where there is a need for equal distribution, while fair is applicable in situations where there is a need for equal treatment and consideration of individual differences.

Harmony.wordDefinition:
Harmony refers to the state of agreement or peaceful coexistence between two or more things. It is applicable in situations where there is a need to create a pleasing or calming effect, such as in music, art, and interpersonal relationships.

Harmony involves a sense of unity and coherence, where all elements work together in a positive way.

Balance is about equal distribution and stability, while harmony is about peaceful coexistence and unity. Both concepts are important in different contexts and can have a positive impact on our lives.

Poise.wordDefinition: Poise refers to an elegant composure in one's behavior or posture. It is about projecting a confident and graceful demeanor, even in situations where one may feel nervous or uncomfortable.

Proportion.wordDefinition:
Balance refers to an equal distribution of weight or force, whereas proportion refers to the relative size or scale of something in comparison to other things.

Proportion describes how the different parts of a whole relate to each other.

In art, balance is used to create a sense of stability and harmony, while proportion is used to create a sense of realism and accuracy in the depiction of objects and figures.

In cooking, balance refers to the correct combination of flavors, while proportion refers to the correct amount of each ingredient used in a recipe.

Balance is used when referring to an equal distribution of weight or force, while proportion refers to the relative size or scale of something in comparison to other things.

Stability.wordDefinition:
Stability refers to the ability of something to resist being toppled or overthrown. It refers to the ability of an object or situation to maintain its position, even in the face of external forces or pressure.

For example, a well-built house can withstand strong winds or earthquakes because of its stability.

Balance applies to situations where there is a need for harmony, coordination, and coherence. Stability applies to situations where there is a need for resistance, endurance, and firmness.

Symmetry.wordDefinition:
Symmetry refers to having corresponding or equal proportions on both sides of an axis or plane.

Balance refers to equal distribution of weight or quantity, while symmetry refers to corresponding or equal proportions on both sides of an axis or plane.

quotes.Text: My family didn't have a lot of money, so I worked my heart out to get my degrees. But the minute I graduated, suddenly everyone was asking me, 'Well, when are you going to get married and start having kids?' And the truth is I had no idea how I would balance the expected role of wife and mother with a challenging career.
quotes.Title: American First Lady
quotes.Name: Michelle Obama

quotes.Text: The major work of the world is not done by geniuses. It is done by ordinary people, with balance in their lives, who have learned to work in an extraordinary manner.
quotes.Title: American Clergyman
quotes.Name: Gordon B. Hinckley

quotes.Text: I balanced all, brought all to mind, the years to come seemed waste of breath, a waste of breath the years behind, in balance with this life, this death.
quotes.Title: Irish Poet
quotes.Name: William Butler Yeats

quotes.Text: I don't trust anyone... It's something that I have to live with, and I have to find the balance of who I want in my life and who isn't good for me.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Selena Gomez

quotes.Text: There's no such thing as work-life balance. There are work-life choices, and you make them, and they have consequences.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Jack Welch

quotes.Text: The challenge of work-life balance is without question one of the most significant struggles faced by modern man.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: Stephen Covey

quotes.Text: Beauty is only skin deep. I think what's really important is finding a balance of mind, body and spirit.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Jennifer Lopez

quotes.Text: A person has got to balance work and life and family in order to be a balanced person.
quotes.Title: American Comedian
quotes.Name: P. J. O'Rourke

quotes.Text: Almost every wise saying has an opposite one, no less wise, to balance it.
quotes.Title: Spanish Philosopher
quotes.Name: George Santayana

quotes.Text: I know that balance that I need to have in my life.
quotes.Title: American Golfer
quotes.Name: Tiger Woods
